title: 110_hr5962
content: The "Keep Our Homes Act of 2008" is a temporary deduction for certain mortgage counseling under section 224 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The deduction for qualified mortgage counseling is limited to $500 per year for individuals. The counseling must be obtained from an organization accredited by the Federal Housing Administration before the loan is issued. The deduction is not allowed for loans not secured by the taxpayer's principal residence. This deduction is not available for amounts paid after December 31, 2012. In 2012, a deduction for certain mortgage counseling was allowed in computing adjusted gross income. Section 224 was amended to include this deduction. A clerical amendment was made to the table of sections, redesignating section 224 as section 225. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. A new section, 225, is added for upside-down mortgages as a temporary deduction. In general, an individual can deduct 20 percent of the excess acquisition indebtedness for their principal residence, limited to $5,000 per year. The deduction is denied for fraudulently obtained mortgages, and it expires after December 31, 2009. The Tax Code was amended in 2009 to allow deductions for upside-down mortgages under section 224. Additionally, a clerical amendment was made to the table of sections, redesignating section 225 as section 226. The Tax Code was amended in 2009 to allow deductions for upside-down mortgages under section 225. A new temporary credit for certain home purchases was introduced under section 25E, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The Tax Code amendment in 2009 introduced a temporary credit for home purchases under section 25E. The credit allows individuals purchasing a qualified principal residence to receive an amount equal to 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas). The credit is divided equally over two taxable years and is only applicable to purchases made after the enactment of the section and within 12 months thereafter. The Tax Code amendment in 2009 introduced a temporary credit for home purchases under section 25E. The credit allows individuals purchasing a qualified principal residence to receive an amount equal to 10% of the purchase price or $7,500 ($9,000 in high-cost areas). The credit is divided equally over two taxable years and is only applicable to purchases made after the enactment of the section and within 12 months thereafter. Additionally, the credit amount is subject to reduction based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income. The term 'modified adjusted gross income' for tax purposes includes adjusted gross income increased by certain exclusions. The credit allowed under subsection (a) is limited by the regular tax liability and other credits for the taxable year. If a credit is claimed for a qualified principal residence purchase, it can only be claimed once. The credit for the purchase of a qualified principal residence is limited to one per individual or married couple. If multiple individuals purchase a residence together, no credit is allowed if any of them have claimed the credit before. A qualified principal residence is defined as a residence purchased to be the purchaser's main residence. The term 'principal residence' has the same meaning as in section 121. No credit is allowed under this section if a credit is allowed under section 1400C. If a taxpayer disposes of the qualified principal residence within 24 months of purchase or fails to occupy it as their principal residence, the remaining portion of the credit will be disallowed. Special rules apply for joint purchases, including married individuals filing separately. Special rules apply for joint purchases of qualified principal residences. For married individuals filing separately, the credit amount is $3,500 instead of $7,000. For unmarried individuals purchasing together, the credit amount can be allocated among them as determined by the Secretary, not exceeding $7,000 in total. Additional rules regarding purchase and purchase price apply, along with a reporting requirement. The enactment date of this section applies, along with reporting requirements. A basis adjustment is made for the purchase of a residence with a credit. Conforming amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments are made to various sections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including inserting new sections and updating existing ones to include references to section 25E. Section 25E provides a credit for certain home purchases, with amendments applying to purchases in taxable years after the enactment of the Act. The amendment is subject to the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001. Additionally, a temporary additional standard deduction for real property taxes is provided for nonitemizers. In 2008 or 2009, a real property tax deduction is added to the Internal Revenue Code, allowing taxpayers to deduct eligible state and local real property taxes up to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns). The term 'eligible State and local real property taxes' refers to State and local real property taxes that have not increased for residential properties since April 2, 2008, until January 1, 2009. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. SEC. 6. TEMPORARY EXCLUSION OF UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION FROM GROSS INCOME. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to exclude unemployment compensation from gross income for individuals in 2008 or 2009. Effective for amounts received after December 31, 2007.
